name: AnthropicModel

input.content:
I'm making pancakes for breakfast.
I added a cup of flour, a teaspoon of salt, and a few tablespoons of sugar to a bowl.
I stirred it together, then added a cup of milk, a beaten egg, and a few tablespoons of oil, and stirred until just mixed.
Then I put 1/4 a cup on a hot frying pan, and flipped it when brown. But they're terrible! Why? List the main reason.

output:
The main reason your pancakes turned out terrible is likely because you forgot to add a leavening agent, such as baking powder or baking soda. Leavening agents are crucial in pancake batter because they create bubbles and help the pancakes rise, resulting in light and fluffy pancakes.

Without a leavening agent, your pancakes will be dense, flat, and possibly undercooked in the middle. The typical ratio is about 1 to 1 1/2 teaspoons of baking powder per cup of flour.

To fix your pancake batter, try adding 1 to 1 1/2 teaspoons of baking powder to your current mixture, and stir gently until just combined. This should help improve the texture and taste of your pancakes.
